>>178075087
I watched this for the first time a couple of weeks ago. It's so fucking terrible that I was fascinated by it. Every new pointless Macguffin, every fake-out, every plot development reversed in less time than it took to set up, it was like some ADD and cocaine-fueled fever dream of what a Star Wars movie is. So many tone-deaf beats that I finished up amazed at it all. It was like someone used the Opposite George method to put it together - "Whatever your instincts say, do the opposite."

I reached a point where I could frequently predict what was coming by imagining the worst possible choice, truly a masterpiece of bad filmmaking. And don't get me wrong, "fascinated" does not imply that I actually enjoyed the experience. It was more akin to watching that video of the dancing kid wooing that chick who was way out of his league or watching a trainwreck. You can't look away from the disaster.

>>178065283
The unsubstantiated rumour that I heard was that Gizmo is in fact, extremely old, but has remained in the infant stage of his species lifecycle indefinitely, making him never age. The old man had inherited Gizmo as a teenager himself. The family were philosophers and were wealthy back in China(where philosophy was more about 'think but get money' a lot sooner than in the West), but centuries of 'incidents' with their 'ancestral Mogwai'(actually alien) led them to be weary of technological progress that the monsters thrived on. The family survived off self-sufficiency and selling their belongings, sometimes as antiques, until the old man who now has them all in a shop, Gizmo included.

It's like the Gremlins are designed to be massively dangerous in advanced societies. In primitive ones with daily routine dictated by available light, responsibility given to children early and treated seriously, longer folk-memory due to oral traditions and no mass-media all mean no Mogwai would ever progress to cocoon and be kept with the preserved food is to stay dry. Life and death choices were a daily thing, the mindset different. Letting a Mogwai progress nearly always meant at least some deaths, but killing one was not an option for the old man's family when they came to possess it. We also haven't ever seen a Mogwai die in either film; all the villains become Gremlins. For Gizmo though what would be a satisfying answer for why he's the only one that's good would be; he was taught to be, and he learned to ignore the impulses of his kind but always feels them. Gizmo is good because Gizmo is trying, all the time, like everyone else.

>>178073544
Not setting up the second generation of Avengers properly is the biggest misstep in cinema history, and has basically destroyed the MCU.
They should have had a natural B team of younger heroes ready to step into the shoes of the originals. Infinity War and Endgame should have showcased the natural successors to the team, and Phase 4 should have been all movies focused on the new Avengers individually dealing with with the fallout of the snap and a post-Tony world, with the occasional team-up. Just like the Phase 1 structure that started it all; set up each hero in their own movie, bring them together as a team for Avengers: Rebirth or some shit, with a brand new super-villain for them to prove themselves against. Spidey was the only one they really did this with, and he's not even there anymore.

Since Endgame this whole universe has felt stupid and unsatisfying, there should never be any hesitation when the average viewer thinks "Who are the Avengers?", and the answer certainly shouldn't be "They're all fucking dead so who cares?"

posts.com: >"It is on a day like this one, a little later, a little earlier, that you discover, without surprise, that something is wrong, that you don't know how to live and that you never will. Something has broken. You no longer feel some thing which until then fortified you. The feeling of your existence, the impression of belonging to or being in the world, is starting to slip away from you. Your past, your present and your future merge into one. You are 25 years old, you have 29 teeth, three shirts and eight socks, 500 francs a month to live on, a few books you no longer read, a few records you no longer play. You don't want to remember anything else. Here you sit, and you only want to wait, just to wait until there's nothing left to wait. You go back to your room, you undress, you slip between the sheets, you turn out the light, you close your eyes. Now is the time when dream-women, too quickly undressed, crowd in around you, the time when you reread ad nauseam books you've a read a thousand times before, when you toss and turn for hours without getting to sleep. This is the hour when your eyes wide open in the darkness, you hand groping towards the foot of the narrow bed in search of an ashtray, matches, a last cigarette, you calmly measure the sticky extent of your unhappiness. Unhappiness did not swoop down on you, it insinuated itself almost ingratiatingly. How many times you have repeated the same amputated gesture, the same journey's that lead nowhere? All you have left to fall back on are your tuppeny-halfpenny boltholes, your idiotic patience, the thousand and one detours that always lead you back unfailingly to your starting point. All that counts is your solitude: whatever you do, wherever you go, nothing that you see has any importance, everything you do, you do in vain, nothing that seek is real. Solitude alone exists, every time you are confronted, every time you face yourself"

https://mashable.com/article/avatar-the-way-of-water-3d-high-framerate-hfr-explained
>Cameron’s myriad press appearances in recent months have clarified how The Way of Water will use this divisive, unusual tool. Certain parts of the movie will project at the usual 24fps and other parts at 48fps.
>First off, it sounds like you don’t need to worry about it if you see the movie in 2D.
>"The one thing I will say pretty definitively is that 48 frames doesn't benefit a 2D movie very much, if at all,” Cameron told Yahoo News. “It's really about making a better experience in 3D.”
>As for which parts of The Way of Water will look smoother than others, Cameron addressed that in the same interview. Put simply, if a scene is underwater, it’ll project at 48fps. There may also be flying scenes and other outdoor shots shown that way, but it sounds like all that underwater action is where you’ll see HFR the most.
>Cameron also admitted that it’s not a great idea to use HFR for other, more mundane scenes.
>"If it's just people sitting around talking or walking and talking, relatively slowly evolving images, it's not necessary,” he told Yahoo News. "In fact, it's actually sometimes even counter-productive because it looks a little too glassy-smooth, right? So the trick to it was to figure out where to use it and where not to use it."

https://www.thegamer.com/avatar-the-way-of-water-3d-dolby-imax/
>Dolby 3D, available on Dolby screens, is the most sophisticated of the bunch. Dolby’s 3D glasses were developed using a process called Six Primary 3D that interprets six different wavelengths of color, three to each eye, which creates what Dolby calls stereo contrast to eliminate ghosting and provide a clearer image. It’s two to four times brighter than the others and takes advantage of Dolby’s HDR, meaning the image has brighter brights and darker darks. Avatar: The Way of Water was created using the Dolby Vision 3D system and Dolby partnered with James Cameron’s production company, Lightstorm Entertainment, to provide the studio with the tools and technology it needed to create 3D for Avatar. In the simplest terms, Dolby 3D can be seen as a native 3D format for the film. The Way of Water is meant to be seen in Dolby 3D.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I would give my thoughts on this show (which I actually liked, but I watched it drunk / high) but they're schizo.

Basically school as being systemically a mind control program to brutalize kids (in which Hannah was the one who "didn't make it out alive"), and the school elites very much a precursor to the future generation of Illuminati, e.g. Bryce Walker whose family basically owned the school and would have probably gone on to a successful career in politics if he never faced exposure, reflection, and ultimately ending up dead.

A few syncs:

-There are strong indications S2 originally had Tyler follow through with his Columbine plans, e.g. in the dance scene you hear someone cry "He's got a gun!" This change was a fortunate one, since the S2's premiere coincided with the massacre in Santa Fe, TX.

-The striking resemblance between Bryce Walker and Brett Kavanaugh, the latter's high-profile hearing also coinciding with the release of S2. You may recall that Kavanaugh's patently stage-managed courtroom drama built Kamala Harris' "progressive" cred, not a coincidence.

-The students rioting against police in S4 virtually coincided with the Floyd riots, despite the series having been written, filmed, produced, etc. well in advance of his death. Even people on the subplebbit were commenting on how weird that was.

All this is of course part of a pattern of television / film mysteriously foreshadowing real-life events, going back to the pilot episode of "The Lone Gunmen" aired Mar. 2001 featuring a plot by a hard right government faction to crash a passenger airplane from Boston Logan into the WTC in order to create a pretext for a Middle East war.
https://web.archive.org/web/20120514112024/http://killtown.911review.org/lonegunmen.html

But yes, I enjoyed it. It is cringe but a lot of things are, and the editing, music, and romance of this one guy unraveling how his whole social structure systemically blows was enjoyable, with alcohol at least.

The best part is, we don't even have to argue the physical evidence. While a careful review will show that it does not support the official version, the circumstantial aspect of the case is equally compelling.

The House Select Committee on Assassinations concluded, based on the witnesses they interviewed, that Lee Harvey Oswald had an association of unspecified nature with David Ferrie and Clay Shaw before the assassination. This confirmed the earlier findings of the New Orleans District Attorney's Office, which found multiple witnesses who saw Oswald with Ferrie and / or Shaw. Some of them testified under oath at the Shaw trial, with no conceivable gain (and considerable risk, as the D.A.'s witnesses were subject to a pattern of threats, harassment, and violence - which seems quite strange, if one is to believe the case against Shaw was based in fantasy).

Both Ferrie and Shaw were on record denying any relationship with Oswald, or each other for that matter (despite the fact that witnesses to a Shaw / Ferrie association are well into the double digits). Yet the House Committee concluded Oswald, Ferrie, and Shaw knew each other, meaning the latter two lied to investigators. I can't fathom an innocuous explanation for that, and when both men turn out to have extensive ties with the Central Intelligence Agency some more sinister possibilities become apparent.
